questions.question:
Question 1: A biopsy done for a chronic verrucous lesion over the right cheek in an elderly man revealed 
the given histopathological finding. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows keratin pearls which are characteristic of squamous cell 
carcinoma. Squamous cell carcinoma is characterized by the proliferation of atypical squamous 
cells with horn pearls/keratin pearls.

questions.question:
Question 2: During rounds, you have been asked to examine a patient with an ulcer over the face. Which 
of the following features will raise the suspicion of it being squamous cell carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
On examination of an ulcer, everted margins will be suggestive of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC). SCC is the second most common skin cancer, while BCC is the most common skin cancer. 
Variants of SCC in-situ include: • Bowen's disease • Erythroplasia of Queyrat SCC initially presents as smooth nodular, verrucous, papillomatous lesions. These lesions then 
ulcerate and form a characteristic, everted edge, surrounded by inflamed, indurated skin. Surgical excision is the treatment of choice. Other modalities of treatment include: • Cautery ablation • Cryotherapy • Drug therapy including imiquimod • Moh’s microsurgery • Radiation therapy The below image shows SCC with everted margins: 1253 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: 1242 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following can increase the risk of developing squamous cell carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
HPV 6 & 11 are not risk factors for squamous cell carcinoma, HPV 16 & 18 are risk 
factors for squamous cell carcinoma. Note: Skin cancer is the most frequent malignant neoplasm in organ transplant recipients, with 
SCC and BCC representing 95% of cancer.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is not true regarding squamous cell carcinoma?

options.a: Skin biopsy is mandatory in all cases
options.b: Mohs micrographic surgery is indicated for recurrent tumors
options.c: Broder's staging is based on the depth of the lesion
options.d: Lesion on the ear is a high-risk feature

questions.explanation:
Broder's staging for SCC is based on histological grading. Depth or size of the tumor and lymph 
node involvement are not included in Broder's staging. 1254 
Sold by @itachibot A skin biopsy is mandatory in all patients with suspected squamous cell carcinoma. Mohs 
micrographic surgery is indicated in patients with aggressive and high-risk SCC. High-risk features of SCC include: • Perineural invasion • Depth of lesion greater than 2 mm • Lesions on the ear • Poorly differentiated lesions Note: Mohs micrographic surgery is the treatment of choice in BCC.

questions.question:
Question 5: A 55-year-old farmer presented with a slow-growing lesion over his left hand for the past 5 
months. The lesion was initially nodular, which then ulcerated. On examination, a 2 x 1 cm 
ulcer with everted margins was noted. Biopsy revealed keratin pearls. Which of the following 
stains will be positive for this condition?
questions.explanation:
SCC is a malignant tumor of keratinizing cells of the epidermis arising from the stratum 
germinatum (basalis) and expresses cytokeratins 1 and 10. CK-20 is specific for Merkel cell carcinoma. BCL2 is used to distinguish between basal cell 
carcinomas and trichoepitheliomas. HMB-45 is used to detect melanocytes.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 75-year old man came with complaints of a painless nodule on the left palm for the past 4 
weeks. He gave a history of sustaining a thorn prick injury to the palm 5 weeks ago. On 
examination, the lesion appears as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? 1243 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and image showing an exophytic nodule with central keratinous debris is 
suggestive of keratoacanthoma. Keratoacanthoma is a low-grade squamous cell carcinoma. It presents clinically as a proliferating 
dome-shaped keratin-filled crater. Patients usually give a prior history of minor trauma. 
Treatment of choice is an excisional procedure with 4 mm margins. Option A: Actinic keratoses consist of hyperkeratotic erythematous papules and patches on the 
sun-exposed skin. They arise in middle-aged to older adults and have some potential for 
malignant transformation. 1255 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: Bowen's disease appears histologically as SCC in situ. It initially presents with a red- 
dened□ area that progresses to thickened plaques and may vary from small lesions (<1 cm) to 
large areas. When it is confined to the glans penis or vulva, Bowen disease is sometimes referred 
to as Erythroplasia of Queyrat. Option D: Mycosis fungoides is a cutaneous T cell lymphoma, and plaque-stage lesions are seen. 1256 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A firefighter presented with a chronic non-healing painless ulcer over his left leg. He gave a 
history of sustaining 2nd-degree burns injury to the leg 10 years back during a rescue 
mission. The examination finding is as shown below. All of the following are true about this 
condition, except  
. 1244 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and image showing an irregular ulcer with cauliflower shaped granulation 
tissue points to a diagnosis of Marjolin’s ulcer. It is avascular.

questions.question:
Question 8: A 65-year-old man has the following lesion over the face. He complains of bleeding while 
itching. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.explanation:
The given history with the image showing an ulcer over the face with pearly, rolled-out borders 
points to a diagnosis of basal cell carcinoma. Basal cell carcinoma (BCC) is an epithelial tumor arising from basal cells. It is the most common 
type of skin cancer most commonly seen over the face, above the line joining corner of the mouth, 
and lobule of the ear. Risk factors for BCC include ultraviolet radiation (strongest risk factor), age 
40-80 years with excessive sun exposure, light-skinned people, and exposure to arsenic 
compounds, coal tar, aromatic hydrocarbons, and infrared light. It is more common in males than 
females. It is also associated with syndromes such as xeroderma pigmentosum and Gorlin's 
syndrome. Features of BCC include: • Pearly nodule with rolled border • Tortuous telangiectatic vessels • Surface which can get ulcerated with raised and beaded edge, often with a central depression or 
umbilication • Bleeding on minor trauma BCC has various subtypes such as nodular (most common type), pigmented, nodulocystic, 
morphoeic, infiltrative, and fibroepithelioma of Pinkus. 1257 
Sold by @itachibot It is locally aggressive and can erode the bone or facial sinuses. It rarely metastasizes via lymph 
nodes. The occasional presence of melanin in the nodular variant of BCC (pigmented BCC) may lead to 
confusion with melanoma. Depending upon the type of the lesion, a shave, punch or excisional biopsy may be employed for 
diagnosis. X-ray or CT may be needed if there is a local invasion. Histology shows peripheral 
palisading of cells. Treatment: • Surgical: Wide excision (4-6 mm clearance) with a skin graft or flap or primary suturing • Mohs' surgery for BCC close to the eyes, nose, or ear to preserve more tissue. • Non-surgical: Radiotherapy, vismodegib and sonedegib. Other options: Option A: Dermatofibrosarcoma, also known as dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) is a 
rare, slow-growing, well-differentiated primary fibrosarcoma of the skin, associated with increased 
production of platelet-derived growth factor-beta. It presents as a protuberant nodule within a 
firm, indurated plaque that can ulcerate. They are locally aggressive tumors with high recurrence 
rates. Treatment is wide excision and Mohs microscopic surgery. Imatinib is used for 
unresectable, metastatic, and recurrent tumors. The given image below shows a DFSP near the 
umbilicus. Option B: Marjolin's ulcer is a painless, slow-growing, locally malignant, well-differentiated 
squamous cell carcinoma that occurs in a chronic scar (burns scar, scar of venous ulcer). It 
presents as an indurated, non-tender ulcer with raised and everted edges with scarring in the 
surrounding area with marked fibrosis. The ulcer can spread to the lymph nodes when it reaches 
the normal skin. A wedge biopsy and MRI of the region involved confirm the diagnosis. 
Management is by wide excision, for larger ulcers, amputation is done. The given image below 
shows a marjolin's ulcer of the leg. 1258 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Naevus is a common benign neoplasm caused due to mutations in the components of 
the RAS signaling pathway. It has various types, such as congenital naevus, blue naevus, Spitz 
naevus, halo naevus, and dysplastic naevus. The given image below shows a patient with multiple 
dysplastic nevi.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is true regarding basal cell carcinoma?

options.a: Nodular is the most common type
options.c: Most commonly seen over the neck
options.d: Only punch biopsy is used for diagnosis

questions.explanation:
The most common form of BCC (60%) is the nodular variant. Other types of BCC are: • Superficial BCC- typically appears on the trunk as a pink or erythematous plaque with a thin 
pearly border • Infiltrative BCC 1259 
Sold by @itachibot • Pigmented variant of nodular BCC • Morpheaform variant - is an uncommon variant and is the most aggressive form • Fibroepithelioma of Pinkus Option B: Patients with BCC show excellent prognosis with 100% survival rates for cases that have 
not spread to other sites. Option C: Most of the basal cell carcinoma occurs on the face above the line joining the corner of 
the mouth and lobule of the ear. Option D: Depending upon the type of lesion, a shave, punch, or exicision biopsy can be used to 
confirm the diagnosis. The below image shows a nodular BCC

questions.question:
Question 10: Lymph node involvement may be seen in patients with all of the following cutaneous 
malignancies except?
questions.explanation: Basal cell carcinoma does not show lymphatic or hematogenous metastasis. It is locally invasive.

questions.question:
Question 11: A construction worker presented to the clinic with a slowly enlarging lesion near the left inner 
canthus for the past 2 years. He noticed bleeding from the lesion for the past 2 months. On 
examination, a 3 x 1 cm ulcer with pearly rolled-out margins was noted. A biopsy was done. 
Which of the following is the characteristic finding that will be seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The characteristic finding of basal cell carcinoma is of ovoid cells in nests with a single 'palisading' 
layer. The cells of a BCC resemble those of the basal layer of the epidermis. They are basophilic, have a 
large nucleus, and appear to form a basal layer by forming an orderly line around the periphery of 
tumor nests in the dermis, a feature referred to as palisading. 1260 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 12: In patients with BCC, Mohs microscopic surgery will be indicated for which of the following 
features of the tumor?
questions.explanation:
Moh’s microscopic surgery is indicated in patients with the following features of BCC: • Primary lesions of the ear or lip • Recurrent lesions • With perineural invasion • Poorly differentiated lesions • Tumors more than 2 cm in size Moh’s microscopic surgery involves initial surgical excision of the tumor, followed by repeated 
tissue sampling along lateral and deep margins. These tissue samples are examined immediately 
under a frozen section for evidence of tumor. This process is repeated until the clearance is finally 
obtained. 1261 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in a patient with Gorlin syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Osteoma is not a part of Gorlin syndrome. Gorlin syndrome/basal cell naevus syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition caused by a 
mutation in the PTCH gene. Components of Gorlin syndrome include: • Basal cell carcinomas • Medulloblastoma • Bifid ribs • Odontogenic keratocysts

questions.question: Question 14: ABCDE rule applies for:
questions.explanation:
ABCDE algorithm is used to diagnose melanoma. It comprises of: • Asymmetry • Border irregularity • Color variegation • Diameter of more than 6 mm • Evolution or change Melanoma is a malignant tumor arising from melanocytes at the epidermal-dermal junction. 
Though it represents only 4% of skin cancers, it accounts for 80% of deaths (high mortality rate). 1262 
Sold by @itachibot It presents as a pigmented lesion that has enlarged, ulcerated, or bled. Histopathological confirmation is the gold standard in the diagnosis of melanoma. It is divided 
into four main types: nodular melanoma (NM), superficial spreading melanoma (SSM), lentigo 
maligna melanoma (LMM), and acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM). The treatment consists of wide local excision of the tumor and follow-up to detect any local 
recurrence around the scar and excluding nodal spread.

questions.question:
Question 15: An anxious patient with a black mole over his back presents to the clinic for evaluation. All of 
the following features according to the ABCDE rule will point towards a diagnosis of 
melanoma in this patient except?
questions.explanation: D stands for diameter >6 mm and not depth > 6mm.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is not true regarding malignant melanoma?

options.a: Lentigo maligna type has the worst prognosis
options.d: Acral melanoma is the most common type in dark-skinned individuals

questions.explanation:
Lentigo maligna melanoma has the best prognosis. Nodular melanoma has the worst prognosis. Option B: Malignant melanoma arises from melanocytes at the dermo-epidermal junction 
(junctional melanocytes). They may also arise from mucosal surfaces of the eyes, pharynx, 
esophagus, anorectal and genital areas. Option C: Malignant melanoma most commonly metastasizes to the lungs. Option D: Acral melanoma is the most common type in dark-skinned individuals.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is the most common type of malignant melanoma?
questions.explanation:
Superficial spreading melanoma is the most common type of malignant melanoma. It usually 
arises in a pre-existent naevus. Other types of malignant melanoma include: • Nodular melanoma - presents as a nodule, and has the worst prognosis. • Acral lentiginous melanoma - commonly seen over palms and soles. Most common melanoma in 
dark-skinned individuals. • Lentigo maligna melanoma - also known as Hutchinson's melanotic freckle. More commonly 
seen on sun-exposed areas like the face, neck, or hands of the elderly. It is the least common and 
has the best prognosis.

questions.question: Question 18: What does the finding depicted in the image signify?
questions.explanation:
The image shows Hutchinsons's nail sign in subungual melanoma. It arises from the nail matrix, 
most commonly in the great toe or thumb. 1263 
Sold by @itachibot Hutchinson's nail sign is an important clinical clue to subungual melanoma. It is characterized by 
the extension of brown or black pigment from the nail bed, matrix, and nail plate to the adjacent 
cuticle and proximal or lateral nail folds. It is also associated with nail dystrophy. Note: Pseudo-Hutchison’s sign is a reflection of the pigmentation of the nail bed and nail matrix 
through the transparent nail folds. Option A: Subungal hematoma is a close differential of subungual melanoma. It is seen secondary 
to trauma which causes bleeding and resultant hematoma formation and pigmentation. It is 
important to note that the features of Hutchinson's nail sign are not seen with subungual 
hematoma. Option B: Nodular melanoma is a condition where malignant melanoma cells proliferate 
downwards through the skin – this is known as vertical growth. The lesion presents as 
a nodule that has been rapidly enlarging. 1264 
Sold by @itachibot Option D: Lentigo maligna is an early form of melanoma, in which the malignant cells are 
confined to the tissue of origin, the epidermis, hence it is often reported as in-situ melanoma. Note: Subungual melanoma can be either superficial spreading melanoma or acral lentiginous 
melanoma. A difference of opinion has been noted in Bailey and Love, 27th ed. where it has been 
mentioned that melanoma under the fingernail is usually superficial spreading 
melanoma. However, most dermatology textbooks including the Rooks 9th ed. and Fitzpatrick's 
9th ed and several research articles mentioned subungual melanoma as a variant of acral 
lentiginous melanoma.

questions.question: Question 19: Most common site of lentigo maligna melanoma is
questions.explanation:
Lentigo maligna melanoma also known as Hutchison’s melanotic freckle is more commonly seen 
on sun-exposed areas like face, neck or hands of the elderly. It is the least common and least 
malignant type.

questions.question:
Question 20: 1248 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following can be used for staging patients with melanoma?
questions.explanation:
Both Breslow and Clark’s system is used for melanoma staging. Breslow thickness is the depth of invasion measured from the granular layer of the epidermis to 
the base of the lesion. As the thickness of the melanoma increases, the prognosis worsens. Clark's 
is based on the layer of skin to which melanoma has invaded. Breslow thickness has largely supplanted Clark's as it is a more accurate method of predicting 
prognosis. Van-nyus prognostic index is used for DCIS. Atlanta's is used for acute pancreatitis. 1265 
Sold by @itachibot Onodera's prognostic index is used for hepatocellular carcinoma after initial hepatectomy

questions.question:
Question 21: A farmer presented with a brownish lesion over the plantar aspect of the left foot for 2 years. 
Over the last few months, he noticed that the lesion was increasing in size. On examination, a 
2 x 1.5cm asymmetric lesion with notched edges was noted. Excision biopsy revealed cells 
containing large, pleomorphic nuclei and numerous mitotic figures. Which of the following 
will be used as a marker for this condition?
questions.explanation: The given history and biopsy finding is suggestive of melanoma. S-100 is a marker for melanoma. Other markers for melanoma are: • MELAN-A • HMB (Human Melanoma Black)-45 • LDH

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of the following will be the most important prognostic indicator in patients with stage 
1 melanoma?
questions.explanation:
The best prognostic factor in primary stage 1 melanoma (T1N0) is the tumor thickness or depth of 
the melanoma. The presence of lymph node metastases is the single most important prognostic index for 
melanoma in general. But in Stage 1 melanoma, as there is no lymph node involvement, the depth 
of the melanoma is the best prognostic factor. Other major prognostic factors, in order of impact on survival, include: • Presence of lymph node metastases • Ulceration • Age • Anatomic location of the primary tumor • Gender

questions.question: Question 23: Arrange the types of melanoma from best to worst according to their prognosis?
questions.explanation:
The order of prognosis for types of melanoma from better to worse is: Lentigo maligna melanoma (LMM) and acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM) > superficial 
spreading melanoma (SSM) > nodular melanoma (NM) The LMM and ALM both have long horizontal phases. As a result of this, there will be more time 
to detect them before they enter the vertical phase of growth. Thus LMM and ALM have a better 
prognosis than other subtypes. The SSM has an intermediate prognosis, as the horizontal phase is rapidly followed by the vertical 
phase. The NM has the worst prognosis, as there is no horizontal phase and it starts with a vertical 
growth phase. This leads to a greater average tumor thickness. 1266 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 24: A patient presented from the dermatology out-patient with a biopsy-proven melanoma on her 
right arm with a Breslow depth of 2.1 mm. Nodes were clinically negative. What is the 
surgical management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Wide local excision with a resection margin of 2 cm along with sentinel lymph node biopsy 
(SLNB) will be recommended for melanomas invading to a depth > 2mm. Recommended margins of wide local excision: Wide local excision with SLNB is preferred for early-stage tumours. SLNB should be performed 
for lesions >1mm in depth. If SLNB is positive or if nodes are clinically positive, lymph node 
dissection should be performed. SLN biopsy is more challenging in the head and neck than in other regions because of the rich 
lymphatic drainage network, and the false-negative rate for SLN biopsy is generally higher for 
melanomas in these locations. Cross-sectional imaging, such as with a single-photon emission CT, 
helps to identify the exact anatomic location of the SLNs more accurately. Dept

questions.question:
Question 25: Which of the following FDA-approved adjuvant therapy will be recommended for patients 
with malignant melanoma?
questions.explanation:
The only systemic adjuvant therapy approved by the US FDA for malignant melanoma is 
high-dose interferon alpha 2b. It is administered at nearly the maximum tolerated dose, with 1 month of intravenous injections 
followed by 11 months of subcutaneous injections three times weekly. Note: Dabrafenib is a BRAF inhibitor used in advanced stages of melanoma.

questions.question: Question 26: Which of the following is false regarding Merkel cell carcinoma?

options.a: Regional lymph nodes will be involved in 30% of the cases
options.b: It is characterized by a rapidly growing, flesh-colored papule
options.d: Wide local excision is usually done

questions.explanation:
Recurrence is common in Merkel cell carcinoma. 1267 
Sold by @itachibot Merkel cell carcinoma is a rare and aggressive neuroendocrine tumor of the skin, most commonly 
found in white men and diagnosed at a mean age of 70 years. A rapidly growing, flesh-colored 
papule or plaque characterizes the disease. Regional lymph nodes are involved in 30% of the patients and 50% will develop systemic 
disease. CK-20 is a specific marker for Merkel cell carcinoma. Wide local excision is usually 
necessary.

questions.question:
Question 27: A lady comes with a reddish firm nodule on her chest which hasn't grown in size. Its 
histolopathological image is shown below. What is the diagnosis? 1250 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of a woman with reddish firm nodule on her chest and histology 
showing multiple dilated vascular structures with a single layer of epithelial cells is suggestive of a 
hemangioma. Hemangioma is a benign tumor caused by the abnormal growth of blood vessels. Types of 
hemangioma are capillary hemangioma (most common), juvenile/ strawberry hemangioma, 
cavernous hemangioma and pyogenic hemangioma. Indications for immediate treatment are complications such as ulceration or those pertaining to 
the location of the mass (e.g. visual issues due to a large hemangioma over the eyelid). Treatment options include: • Beta-blockers - oral propranolol • Steroids - intralesional triamcinolone, topical clobetasol, systemic steroids • Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine - for steroid-resistant lesions • Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser The given image shows a flat to elevated, irregular, pinkish-red mass over the skin of the abdomen 
suggestive of a strawberry hemangioma. The given image shows a capillary hemangioma in a child 1268 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 28: Extra mammary Paget's disease is commonly seen in the:
questions.explanation:
Extramammary Paget's disease arises most frequently on the vulva. Other sites include the 
perineum, scrotum, perianal skin, and penis. Extramammary Paget's disease (EMPD) can be primary or secondary. • Primary EMPD is more common and occurs in the absence of an underlying malignancy, 
thought to arise from intraepidermal parts of apocrine glands or from pluripotent cells from the 
epidermis. • Secondary EMPD arises from an underlying adnexal carcinoma or internal malignancy due to 
the epidermotropic spread of malignant cells from the underlying tumor. Visceral malignancies associated with EMPD are carcinomas of the colon, rectum, bladder, 
urethra, cervix, and prostate. The patient presents with well-defined, moist, erythematous scaly 
plaques and severe pruritis. Lichenification and excoriations may also be seen. Diagnosis is confirmed by punch, wedge, or excisional skin biopsy. A systemic workup should also 
be done to identify any underlying malignancy and they include colonoscopy, cystoscopy, 
colposcopy, and pelvic examination with pap smear in females. Treatment: • Mohs microscopic surgery with 5 cm margin clearance • Radiotherapy • Topical 5-fluorouracil and imiquimod • Chemotherapy • Photodynamic therapy The given image below shows extramammary Paget's disease of the vulva. 1269 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 29: A postmenopausal lady presented with an itchy plaque over the vulva for the past 2 years, 
which persisted despite multiple topical treatments. Biopsy of the lesion revealed large 
vacuolated cells with mucin. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario and presence of large vacuolated cells with mucin (Paget's cells) points to a 
diagnosis of extramammary Paget's disease. It is a form of intraepidermal adenocarcinoma. Extramammary Paget's disease usually presents in the sixth to eighth decades of life. It may occur 
in the genital or perianal regions, or in cutaneous sites rich in apocrine glands such as the 
axilla. Approximately 25% of the cases are associated with an underlying in situ or invasive 
neoplasm. It most commonly presents with pruritus. The clinical appearance is similar to mammary Paget's 
Disease. Scattered areas of erosion and white scale can give rise to a “strawberries and cream” 
appearance. The invasion of the lymphatic system by the tumor gives rise to underpants-pattern 
erythema. Surgical excision forms the basis of treatment. The given image shows large vacuolated cells with mucin (Paget's cells) 1270 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 30: In which of the following subtypes of soft tissue sarcoma is lymph node dissection 
mandatory?
questions.explanation:
Most of the soft tissue sarcomas undergo hematogenous dissemination to metastasize to lungs, 
liver, bones, and subcutaneous tissue. Regional lymph node involvement is relatively uncommon. 
However, the most common subtypes with nodal metastasis are: • Clear cell sarcoma • Liposarcoma • Rhabdomyosarcoma • Angiosarcoma • Epitheloid sarcoma • Malignant fibrous histiocytoma Lymph node involvement is an important prognostic indicator for survival. Hence, lymph node 
dissection is mandatory in these cases. 1271 
Sold by @itachibot
